How to Stop Worrying and Start Living

Dale Carnegie

In a nutshell

Worry is a psychological effect which we can control. Cultivate a mental attitude of peace and happiness, be yourself and don’t stress the little things. Think ‘what is the worst thing that could happen?’ and accept outcomes you can’t influence, including past events. Most worries come from not knowing enough to make a decision; identify the root of the problem and once you have decided what to do, act and be confident in your decision. Keep busy, help others and you’ll find a purpose to drive you.

Understanding the nature of worry

  1. Live in day-tight compartments
  2. When faced with a problem, ask yourself ‘what is the worst thing that could happen?’

Analysing worry

  1. Most worries come from not knowing enough to be confident in a decision
  2. Once you’ve made a decision, act upon it and don’t worry
  3. When faced with a problem, ask:
    • What is the problem?
    • What is the cause of the problem?
    • What are all the possible solutions?
    • What is the best solution?

How to break the habit of worrying

  1. Keeping busy clears your mind of worry
  2. Don’t worry about little problems; don’t let them affect your happiness
  3. Bear in mind that many worries are statistically very unlikely to occur
  4. Accept outcomes we can’t influence
  5. Forgive and forget conflicts of the past; what’s done is done

Stop worrying about criticism

  1. Unjust criticism is often a disguised compliment
    • It often means you have aroused jealousy and envy
  2. Do the very best you can; nobody can ask for any more than that
  3. Be comfortable with critiquing yourself
    • Being self-deprecating is an important hallmark of a leader

Cultivate a mental attitude that brings you peace and happiness

  1. Fill your mind with thoughts of peace, courage, health and hope
    • “our life is what our thoughts make of it”
  2. Don’t worry about trying to get even with people
    • Hating our enemies gives them power over us, and our happiness
  3. Don’t imitate others; find yourself and be yourself
  4. When something bad happens, look for the benefits it could bring
  5. We forget our own unhappiness when we create a little happiness for others

Prevent worry and fatigue

  1. Rest before you get tired
  2. Learn to relax at work and at home
  3. Follow these working habits
    • Clear your desk of all papers except those relating to the problem at hand
    • Do things in order of their importance
    • Don’t put off problems, try and solve them there and then
    • Learn to organise, deputise and supervise
  4. Prevent worry and fatigue by putting enthusiasm into your work
